Colin Green wrote:

> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
>
> >One problem I see with all economic prediction is that it is
> >impossible to predict human ideas, yet ideas are major factors in
> >economic activity.   What is going to be invented next year?  How can
> >we know whether someone will come up with an ingenious marketing idea
> >at an otherwise lackluster company?  Other human initiatives like
> >deciding to take on a rival or even war also are frequently almost
> >impossible to predict until it's too late (at least too late to make
> >an economic gain from the prediction).  Accurately predicting the
> >ideas and initiatives that various individuals will come up is perhaps
> >as difficult as the problem of AI itself, since it would require
> >accurately simulating the thought processes leading up to the
> >decisions.
> >
> >Of course, not to be too pessimistic, there are still some trends that
> >can be followed with a level of success, but I just don't think
> >there's ever going to be an extremely accurate prediction model.
> > 
> >
> {Idea] Many stock price movements are unpredictable, but some of the
> movements may be predictable after effects of the unpredictable moves.
> Therefore the key in making money would be to be ability to determine
> when the predictable movements are occuring (or are about to occur) and
> to trade based on the prediction, and to ignore all other
> non-predictable movements. Therefore something akin to a confidence
> output would probably be a good thing, so instead of always trying to
> predict tomorrows price the network has the ability to admit that it
> doesn't 'understand' the current conditions and therefore won't be
> making a prediction today.
>
> Colin.


This is EXACTLY what I'm trying to do. Events which happen out of the 
blue like Septembet the 11th happen very infrequently.
What's more likely to happen is an event will develop over a period of 
weeks, and the thing driving the price will be the sum total
psychology of all the traders.

I plan to 'show' the last N days worth of stock data to the network and 
get it to return a number from
 -1 to +1 based on sell through to buy. Most of the time I would expect 
the network to return zero values, but once in a while where
it thinks a stock has suddenly entered a predictable domain I would hope 
it would put it's hand up with a strong buy or sell signal. For
1 stock this may happen once every few months, but by applying it to 
every stock in the FTSE 350 and S&P 1000 every night, I
would hope to get a few good candidates a week which would definitely be 
enough to make a lot of money IF (and obviously it's a
big IF) the network has learned to 'fill it's boots' only when it thinks 
there's a very good opportunity available.

Choosing the fitness function to try to drive this sort of behaviour is 
obviously critical - I have a few ideas, I guess I will just have to try
different things out and see what works well on historical time series. 
If you were to take a stock graph for one of the majorly traded stocks
off the yahoo site and label the bottom of the y-axis as 0 and the top 
as 1, you would not be able to work out which stock the graph
belonged to. They all have self similar fractal / chaotic features and I 
think it's fair to lump them all into some sort of 'equivalence class'. 
This only
goes for frequently traded high liquidity stocks though. So I think 
rescaling the data so the y-axis goes from 0->1 is a fair thing to do. 
Especially
when you think that the actual y-axis on the graph on the web page is a 
pixel index in a picture which is always 500 pixels high or whatever.

I have no idea wether any of this will actually work. If it does, then 
I'm in the money. If not, I will have learned a hell of a lot trying.
I'm currently impelementing my own C++ version of NEAT which is heavily 
based on Ken's C++ code, but removing all the redundant stuff like
traits and recurrence which won't be needed for what I'm trying to do.

Emyr
